Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2017 02:06PM - edited Jul 4, 2017 02:07PM by chy12 No, it was a ganglioneuroblastoma, located behind my right lung. It had grown outside of it's "sac" by the time it was found and had wrapped itself around my aorta and spine. it was a successful removal üòä

Posts.Title: I'm googled out, with no answers, and still worried üôÅ chy12 chy12

Posts.Content: chy12 wrote: Hello everyone! I'm new here so forgive my newbie questions. To start, I have many fibroadenomas and dense breast tissue. A few months ago, I started having stabbing pains in my left breast, lasting all day. Uncomfortable enough and distracting enough to prompt another self exam after I got home from work. I found a fairly large lump located at the 6 o'clock position, under my nipple. I had a gyn appt the following week (for a hysterectomy) and she referred me to get a mammogram. To make a long story shorter (sorry!) They found the lump as a large cyst but also found a "mass" beside it. They said it could be another fibroadenoma but they can't be sure because of the dense tissue. they set another appointment for 6 months out to check it again. In the meantime, I've developed a very sore spot, not in my armpit but lower, about two inches. My question is, could this pain (It's persistent and painful to touch sometimes) be related? should I be worried or can I relax? Thank you for listening to me drone on! Any help is appreciated!! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I'm googled out, with no answers, and still worried üôÅ chy12 chy12

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2017 11:02AM chy12 wrote: Thank you so much for replying! They did do an ultrasound and sent the report to my gyno. They didn't give me a copy but sent me a letter saying that the doc thought the mass was probably benign due to the fact that it had a few of the characteristics of the other fibroadenoma that was biopsied before. The letter also said it was very hard to tell because of the dense tissue. They did look under my armpit on the ultrasound but at the time, I didn't have any pain there and there was no mention of anything, so I'm assuming they didn't see anything. I'm probably worrying for nothing but I'm a childhood cancer survivor so I'm always aware of what goes on in my body ‚ò∫

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2017 08:37AM chy12 wrote: Hi Lula! No, I was 1 of 14 trial subjects that they did not use radiation or chemo on for the treatment. I had follow up for 5 years and, thank God, stayed cancer free.
